text: John does Jeremy coming deriving at the
count in Islington this is just
happening now and while we're looking at
him because clearly he'll have taken in
the the extent of the defeat that the
exit poll now the projection is is
putting forward he's waving as he's
coming in he's alive images from the
count in his lectern and as we look at
these images John I'm going to ask you
the direct question you know are you
calling on him to stand down I think
Jeremy will make his own decisions I'm
sure he's thinking about these things
and he will make positions adages
whereas as is right not I do not think
we have to rush into this we need a
period reflection I think we were far
too quick to rush into leadership
elections in 2010 and 2015 we needed
more reflection actually the interregnum
didn't help us in either of on either of
those occasions I I think no I think we
can have if if Jeremy chooses to go at
as he may then I think we should have a
leadership election in the spring and
you know he may well wish to stay on we
haven't gotten either anymore was scared
to face him in this election campaign
scare to debate the arguments but Jeremy
Corbyn I'm sure would be perfectly
willing to face him when they bring
there when they bring their withdrawal
bill next week should hang on for a
while while the party sort of works out
and what to do but I'm intrigued as to
whether or not you think that the party
will have to move on from the kinds of
policies you were putting for ISM and
you're saying in your view they were not
radical and I'd just noted that you said
that we we have to change public
attitudes isn't it actually that the
party has to change its attitude towards
the public I mean isn't that actually
exactly the problem that Alastair
Campbell was putting to you before I
think we do listen to the public and I
think the public are actually
enthusiastic about many of our of our
policies I think Alastair actually
accepted some of that you know we
presented a very you know lengthy bold
manifesto we
was rarely a program for more than a
government it was a program for ten
years plus maybe we should have should
have had a shorter manifesto you know we
didn't have much time to sell you know
some of the newer policies in that but I
think that that program is right because
the state of the economy because the
state of our public services because of
the threat of of climate change is so
dramatic that it requires drastic
solutions and we will still need them at
the next time pause you a second John
sorry and I will bring Alan Duncan in as
well in a second Alan you've been very
patient but because we're on these
images in Islington and Nick Robinson is
there Nick what's the sense of what's
going on there Nick what are you sensing
there and just in terms of the mood
music around the labor leader
well extraordinarily somber you the
labor leaders arrived here at a leisure
center in his constituency just a few
hundred yards away from where he lives
he knows this place incredibly well he
must have dreamt of arriving here to
cheering crowds to the expectation that
he might become prime minister but
instead he comes here knowing that his
days in control of the Labour Party are
coming to an end will the end tonight
probably not but they will end in the
next few days whatever allies like John
Landsman say the Corbin era in the Labor
Party is over the argument that you've
been having in the studio is really
whether his people the people he brought
into the labour party the people who
control the labour party at the moment
can they cling on to control even as mr.
Corbin waves goodbye to the leadership
of the Labour Party that is the argument
taking place and as I look down now here
on jeremy corbyn who is standing just
below me I'm on the gallery the balcony
just above him he's talking to people
he's worked with and been with for not
just years but decades and that's why
the hugs are coming here you can see as
he looks at them he grips them by the
arm he hugs them as if to say it is all
now coming to an end not of course he
in Islington North they'll have a huge
majority here it's a very safe labour
seat but the Corbin project the belief
that his brand of socialism could take
the Labor Party into government that
project is over at least for him
